input: Hi doctor,I am having my Mirena IUD removed today. I have had regular cycles the entire five years of having it. How soon can I conceive?

However, it is important to note that it may take several months for your body to adjust to the hormonal changes associated with the removal of the IUD. It is also important to note that it is possible to become pregnant before your first period after the removal of the IUD. Therefore, it is important to use contraception until you have had a few normal menstrual cycles.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 25 year old woman. I like my skin tone very much. But, I have pigmented skin. I see a lot of discoloration in my face, near my eyes and near mouth. I have consulted a dermatologist and he recommended Vichy cream overnight, which helped me a lot in getting an even skin. But, the wrinkles around my eyes are still there, which make me look aged. I have very much deep tan on my hands, neck and feet area. Please suggest me some body lotion to get even skin tone. I have been using cucumber on my eyes religiously but still no results. Hence, I am requesting for a dermatology recommended eye, face and also body cream. If u can suggest something for daily routine also would be great. I have a dry sensitive skin. I am using Emolene moisturizer and Neutrogena sun block which works well on my skin. I am using Vichy cream at night. Should I include anything more to get even skin? What facial can I go for? Please help.
output: I recommend that you use a gentle cleanser and moisturizer for your face, such as Cetaphil or CeraVe. You can also use a gentle exfoliating scrub once or twice a week to help remove dead skin cells and promote cell turnover. For your body, I recommend using a moisturizing body lotion with SPF, such as Neutrogena's Ultra Sheer Dry-Touch Sunscreen. This will help protect your skin from the sun's harmful rays and keep it hydrated. For your eyes, I recommend using an eye cream with antioxidants, such as Neutrogena's Rapid Wrinkle Repair Eye Cream. This will help reduce the appearance of wrinkles and dark circles. For a facial, I recommend a gentle exfoliating facial, such as a glycolic acid peel. This will help to remove dead skin cells and promote cell turnover. I also recommend using a hydrating mask once or twice a week to help keep your skin hydrated and nourished.

input: Hi doctor,My dentist convinced me to replace my metal filling with a nonmetal filling. After doing it, I got sensitivity to hot food and liquid. Then I went to visit my dentist. It is possible that the filling was placed too close to the nerve, which can cause sensitivity. It is also possible that the filling was not placed correctly, which can also cause sensitivity. A root canal may be necessary if the sensitivity is due to the nerve being irritated. However, it is important to get a second opinion from another dentist or specialist before making any decisions.

input: Hello doctor,Me and my wife got an annual blood test done. Few of my wife\s results are off the radar. She is 30 years old, and she had a mild cough when the tests were done. output: Yes, this is a cause for concern. Monocytes are a type of white blood cell and a low count can indicate an infection or other underlying health condition. An elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) can also indicate an infection or inflammation. It is important to follow up with your doctor to determine the cause of these abnormal results and to discuss any necessary treatment.

input: Hi doctor,My mom is 83 years old. She had a bad fall 1.5 years ago and suffered with a head injury with little internal bleeding and a broken arm. While in hospital, she contracted C.diff and has had several recurring bouts with it. She has had a transplant and so far she is doing well with no recurrence. She also has a fistula near the rectum from an abscess. They put in a tube to keep it open and flowing. She has always had bouts of constipation and diarrhea for years before the accident. Her cognitive functions have been diminishing. One of my brothers is living with her and care taking her for full time.She is very weak, but can walk with the aid of a walker. Before the accident, she was fine. But, she may have shown a few signs of slight memory issues and balance prior to the accident as well. Our main issue right now is loose stools with some fecal incontinence. The doctor said that the fecal incontinence is because of a weak rectum that will not hold back fecal matter. Also, the fistula is always draining. When her stools are normal, she has good energy and cognitive function. When she has loose stools, she is very weak and can hardly stand or walk. Her cognitive function is a lot worse. She gets very confused about daily items and memory issues.We are looking for supplements to keep her regular and avoid the loose stool episodes. These are recurring every other week. Being so weak at the time of an episode, the toilet and the surrounding area get very filthy. She has little control and not able to clean herself properly. Her diet is pretty good. We are trying to keep dairy items away, limiting sugar and some carbohydrates as best as we can.We are giving her Metamucil when she has loose stools as well as some ammonium. This seems to have very limited success. She is on a blood pressure medicine as well as on Coumadin. So, we have to watch for interactions between everything. Regarding supplements, right now she is taking Alpha-GPC, Prevagen and multivitamins B for cognitive help, Fish oil, turmeric and Centrum multivitamins.Any help or suggestions to prevent the loose stools without creating constipation would be appreciated. I would also like to increase her core energy, so she will feel more like moving around. We have a physical therapist at once a week.
output: I would recommend that your mother speak with her doctor about her symptoms and the medications she is taking. It is important to make sure that the medications she is taking are not causing her loose stools. Additionally, her doctor may be able to recommend a stool softener or other medication to help with her symptoms. Additionally, probiotics may be helpful in restoring the balance of bacteria in her gut and helping to reduce the episodes of loose stools. Additionally, increasing her fiber intake may help to reduce the episodes of loose stools. Increasing her intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains may help to increase her fiber intake. Finally, increasing her physical activity may help to increase her energy levels and help her to feel more like moving around.

I hope this information is helpful. Please feel free to contact us if you have any further questions.

input: Dear doctor,For four days, I have very watery diarrhea, cramps, and nausea. Vomiting only twice. Yesterday, I was prescribed Levofloxacin 500 mg for four days. input: Hello doctor,I just want to consult about my skin condition that happens annually. Every year, my hands has this condition where it will itch and form rashes with liquid inside then skin itself. Most of the time, it starts on December then end on February, however it differs every year. This year it started on March and up to now. I experience this every year, as in yearly so I assumed it is normal. It is not hereditary, I assume, because none of my family members is experiencing it other than me.My mother told me that maybe it is because of cold weather which I agreed. It is there for the past 11 years. I have never consulted any professionals about it since it does not look severe. However, I am curious what is this condition called.
output: This sounds like a condition called chronic hand eczema. It is a type of eczema that is characterized by recurrent episodes of itching, redness, and scaling of the skin on the hands. It is often triggered by cold weather, as well as other environmental factors such as contact with irritants or allergens. Treatment typically involves the use of topical corticosteroids and moisturizers to reduce inflammation and itching. If the condition does not improve with these treatments, your doctor may recommend other treatments such as phototherapy or oral medications.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 31 year old female. Height is 5\3" and weight 71 kg. I have normal skin. I have started developing fine lines on my face. Just recently I have developed a slight depression in the form of a line starting from under the inner side of the eye running down the cheek (photo attached). I think this is the beginning of cheek sagging. Is this premature aging? Can this be reverted with non-invasive techniques like topical anti-aging serums, facials, massages or exercises?Someone suggested me to use Retinol-A, which I have started using and is suiting me well. I have read a lot about the benefits of topical retinoid, vitamin E and C serum. Please suggest the best ones as I have heard that most of the available vitamin C serums in the market are useless as they oxidize easily and do not penetrate the skin. I have seen some videos of facial exercises online. Do you think they are effective? Also let me know how often should I get facials and which one is for anti-aging? I am also trying to put down weight. In this process I will naturally lose some fat from my face as well, but I do not want my facial skin to become loose. What should I do for this?
output: It sounds like you are taking the right steps to address your premature aging concerns. Retinol-A is a great choice for anti-aging, as it helps to reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles. Vitamin C and E serums can also be beneficial, but you should make sure to choose a quality product that is designed to penetrate the skin. Facial exercises can be effective, but you should consult with a professional to make sure you are doing them correctly. As for facials, you should get one every 4-6 weeks to help keep your skin looking its best. To prevent your facial skin from becoming loose, you should focus on eating a healthy diet and exercising regularly. This will help to keep your skin toned and firm.

input: Hello doctor,I am 47 today. I went to my primary doctor three years ago with low libido and poor quality erections. Blood work came back as total testosterone 381 and A1c 6.9. Started exercising and lost weight and inches, 198 lbs to 178, 38-inch waist to 32. Symptoms still persisted. The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.
output: Testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis, but it is important to note that it is not a diagnosis that is widely accepted in the medical community. It is important to note that there are many potential causes of low libido and poor quality erections, and it is important to rule out any underlying medical conditions before considering testosterone replacement therapy. If you do decide to try testosterone replacement therapy, it is important to discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. It is also important to note that testosterone replacement therapy is not a permanent solution and should be used with caution. Additionally, it is important to note that Clomid may not be the best option for you, as it can have potential side effects. Ultimately, it is important to discuss all of your options with your doctor and make an informed decision about which treatment is best for you.

output: It is difficult to say why you responded to Venlafaxine XR so quickly when you did not respond to SSRIs. It is possible that the combination of Lamictal and Venlafaxine XR is more effective for you than the SSRIs alone. It is also possible that the Venlafaxine XR is more effective for you than the SSRIs. It is important to discuss any changes in your medication regimen with your doctor before making any changes. Increasing the Venlafaxine XR to 150 mg may help with your energy and motivation, but it may also increase your anxiety and depressive symptoms. input: Hi doctor,One year back, while sitting on a chair in office I felt as if my back got stuck and was unable to move. I took two painkillers and managed to sit there for a while, but after two to three hours the pain started radiating to leg. I was diagnosed with moderate disc herniation at L4-L5 and L5-S1. I was advised to take bed rest for three months and felt better after five months. Then I got some manipulation done with my lower back and my condition got worse. After that I had slight pain in my tail bone while walking and the pain got worse when I sit for five minutes. It got radiated to hips, thighs and it was worse when I stood up from a sitting position. Then I left with no option except bed rest for another four months that is a total nine months of bed rest. After that I suddenly started walking two to three hours a day in a stretch and started doing some exercises. After few days of getting my body too much into motion I felt my upper back getting stuck and again was unable to move and the pain radiated to my wrist and hand. Then had bed rest for another 10 days and felt a bit better. But, still in pain and resumed with two to three hours of brisk walking and exercises. I noticed that many joints in my body were making cracking sound while I walk or move my body and they were continuous. They are not going away no matter how much I move that joint, the cracking sound will repeat infinite times whenever I move my body. The cracking sound is mostly from lower and upper back, shoulder, ankle, foot fingers, knees also make that cracking sound and it is painful as well. Cracking sound in knees are felt more when I start walking after being in rest state and frequency of cracking sound reduces after walking for two to three minutes.I got my ESR and CRP checked. They are normal, but there is a slight increase in lymphocytes and RBC. Now, I have been suffering from this continuous cracking sounds and pain in almost all my joints for more than a month now. I also suffer from severe pain in tail bone area. Also suffers from some sensation loss (not persistent) in left side of my upper left leg, pain in groin area (but not anymore), pain in lower back and upper back. Also a few days back a physiotherapist did some manipulation, which again increased my problem and after that when I wake up in morning both my hands are badly at asleep. Doctors say that discs are hydrated and it is rather some other thing which is causing me problems but are unable to diagnose. The amount of rest I have taken and all those manipulations have gone through have only done badly rather than doing any good. I am only 27 years old and unable to do simple tasks like sitting for five minutes. Please help me, what could be the possible reason for all this.I had some back pain three years ago. My lifestyle is also not good. I do not used to any exercise or walk earlier, only sitting on a chair in front of a computer for 10-11 hours. I have also gained weight of 15 kg in 10 months. Right now, I am taking only Vitamin D3 supplement. I am attaching all my reports for your reference.
output: It sounds like you may have a condition called ankylosing spondylitis. This is a type of inflammatory arthritis that affects the spine and other joints. It can cause pain, stiffness, and cracking sounds in the joints. It can also cause fatigue and weight gain. It is important to see a rheumatologist for a proper diagnosis and treatment. They may recommend medications, physical therapy, and lifestyle changes to help manage your symptoms.

input: Hello doctor,I concern that I have angle-closure glaucoma. I took a strong sleeping pill called Trazodone one night and woke up with a decreased vision in the right eye. My left eye became bad three weeks later. It has now been three months with no improvement. Fundus and other clinical examinations are normal. However, an OCT showed nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning.
output: It is possible that you may have angle-closure glaucoma, however, it is difficult to make a definitive diagnosis without further testing. It is important to have a comprehensive eye exam with a dilated fundus exam, visual field testing, and a thorough evaluation of your intraocular pressure. Additionally, further imaging such as optical coherence tomography (OCT) may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis. If angle-closure glaucoma is confirmed, treatment with medications and/or laser therapy may be necessary to reduce the intraocular pressure and prevent further vision loss.

input: My left ear hurts. If i press the back of my ear, it would really hurt. Sometimes it feels itchy and throbbing. Also, it feels like it\s clogged inside. Last month my other felt like this too, I had to take medication for it.

input: Hello doctor,In left shoulder joint minimal fluid seen in the subcoracoid and subdeltoid bursa and also in bicep tendon. Finding symptoms of subcoracoid/ subdeltoid bursitis and mild biceps Tendinosis.
output: Bursitis and tendinosis are both common conditions that can cause pain and discomfort in the shoulder joint. Bursitis is an inflammation of the bursa, a fluid-filled sac that cushions the joint, while tendinosis is an overuse injury of the tendon that connects the muscle to the bone. Treatment for both conditions typically includes rest, ice, physical therapy, and anti-inflammatory medications. In some cases, a corticosteroid injection may be recommended to reduce inflammation. If the condition does not improve with conservative treatment, surgery may be necessary.

input: Hi doctor,The patient met with an accident. She is 47 years old. In the accident, she had a collar bone fracture and a hit in the back of the brain. output:
Thank you for providing the CT scan report. Based on the report, it appears that the patient has suffered a traumatic brain injury due to the accident. The CT scan shows a fracture of the right clavicle, as well as a contusion in the back of the brain. The contusion is causing swelling and bleeding in the brain, which is causing the bulging of the back of the head. The CT scan also shows some spots in the brain, which could be indicative of a hematoma or other type of injury.

Given the severity of the injury, it is important that the patient receive immediate medical attention. The patient should be taken to the nearest emergency room for evaluation and treatment. The medical team will likely order additional tests, such as an MRI, to further assess the extent of the injury. Treatment may include medications, surgery, or other interventions to reduce swelling and bleeding in the brain.

I hope this information is helpful. Please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any further questions or concerns.

input: Hi doctor.I had Pantocid HP after doctor advice and had loose motion 4-5 times. For stopping loose motion what shall I do? For past six days I am taking Pantocid HP kit. input: Hello doctor,Something broke off from one of my teeth, and I would like to know what was it that broke and what I should do about it (if anything). I think it might have been tartar or cementum, but I do not know. They are hard and off whitish (a little yellowing). They are the same as that material that appears roughly along the bottom edges of my lower incisors. I think they are either tartar or cementum, but I do not know. Please let me know what you think they are and what my options are.
output: It is difficult to diagnose the exact material that has broken off from your tooth without seeing it in person. However, it is likely that the material is either tartar or cementum. Tartar is a hard, calcified deposit that forms on the teeth and can be removed by a dental professional. Cementum is a hard, protective layer that covers the root of the tooth and helps to anchor it in the jawbone. If the material is tartar, it is important to have it removed by a dental professional to prevent further damage to the tooth. If the material is cementum, it is likely that no further action is necessary. However, it is important to have a dental professional examine the tooth to ensure that there is no further damage.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 33 year old healthy male. Last month, I had an unfortunate sexual exposure (condom\s head broke off). I quickly pulled out and washed the genital area with a bathing soap. After few days, I started having a slight itching sensation in the penis. I visited a urologist and he asked me to undergo urine routine and culture tests. The urine culture report did not show any bacterial growth, but the urine routine showed some abnormalities. I have attached those two reports. On subsequent visit, the doctor prescribed me a 10 day antibiotic course (Microdox LBX 100 mg) to be taken twice a day. In addition to that, he also asked me to wash the penis with Betadine Povidone-iodine solution twice a day. The antibiotic course got over two days back. But since then, I have been noticing a slight burning sensation after passing urine, especially during morning and afternoon hours. Today, there is a slight pain in the penis. I checked the area, but did not find any abnormality. Please help in resolving this issue.
output: It is difficult to provide a definitive diagnosis without a physical examination. However, based on the information you have provided, it is possible that you may be experiencing a urinary tract infection (UTI). UTIs are caused by bacteria that enter the urinary tract and can cause symptoms such as burning sensation when urinating, pain in the penis, and frequent urination. It is important to follow up with your doctor for further evaluation and treatment. Your doctor may recommend additional tests such as a urine culture or a urine analysis to determine the cause of your symptoms. Treatment may include antibiotics or other medications to help reduce the symptoms. Additionally, it is important to drink plenty of fluids and practice good hygiene to help prevent UTIs.

input: Hello doctor,I suffer from bipolar 2 disorder as well as OCD and social anxiety disorder. output: It sounds like you have tried a variety of medications to treat your bipolar disorder, OCD, and social anxiety disorder, and that none of them have been successful in managing your symptoms. Treatment-resistant depression is a difficult condition to manage, and it is important to work closely with your doctor to find the best treatment plan for you. Your doctor may want to consider adding other medications to your current regimen, such as an atypical antipsychotic or a mood stabilizer, or they may suggest trying a different type of antidepressant. Additionally, your doctor may suggest that you try psychotherapy or other forms of therapy to help manage your symptoms. It is important to keep in mind that finding the right treatment plan can take time, and it is important to be patient and work closely with your doctor to find the best treatment for you.

input: Hello doctor,I was diagnosed with a left branch bundle block a few years back. I have been under the care of a cardiologist to make sure my heart is fine since then. I have done stress echos yearly or every two years since and have been told my heart is otherwise fine. I just had to switch the other doctor because of insurance and my new doctor says old stress echos are irrelevant, that only chemical or nuclear echos work in patients with lbbb. Is this true? I have a strong family history of heart disease, my father survived two heart attacks, mother survived double bypass and my maternal uncle died from a heart attack, all were smokers with high cholesterol and high blood pressure. I am a former smoker. I am a 43-year-old female. I have been exercising six days per week for over 20 years. My cholesterol is high 213 but HDL is 140 and triglycerides are low. I am a little put off by a nuclear stress echo and would prefer the regular exercise. But I want to know what this new doctor says is true? Then I guess I will have to go nuclear. I am currently taking Spironolactone 100 mg for acne, Omeprazole, and multivitamins. I just had an ultrasound of heart and EKG past monday. Doctor did not mention anything other than lbbb that was previously diagnosed.
output: It is true that nuclear stress echocardiograms are more accurate than regular stress echocardiograms in patients with left bundle branch block (LBBB). However, it is not necessary to have a nuclear stress echocardiogram if your other tests have been normal and you have no symptoms. Your doctor may be recommending a nuclear stress echocardiogram due to your family history of heart disease, but it is ultimately up to you to decide if you want to have the test. If you are concerned about the risks associated with a nuclear stress echocardiogram, you can discuss this with your doctor and decide if it is necessary.

input: Hello doctor,I have a lazy eye. My right eye (sph - 0.50 cyl -0.75 axis 10 degrees) and the left eye is fine. I am 24 years old. I am a web developer, I have to work in front of the computer screen more than 13 hours. Kindly answer the following:What should I do? Do I need to change my profession?Is it curable? What is the treatment?Is there any chance of getting other eye affected?
output:
Hello,

Lazy eye, or amblyopia, is a condition in which the vision in one eye is reduced due to the eye not receiving enough stimulation. It is usually caused by an imbalance in the vision between the two eyes, such as one eye being more nearsighted or farsighted than the other.

The good news is that lazy eye is treatable. Treatment usually involves wearing an eye patch over the stronger eye to force the weaker eye to work harder. This can be combined with vision therapy exercises to help strengthen the weaker eye.

In terms of your profession, you should be able to continue working as a web developer. However, it is important to take regular breaks from the computer screen to give your eyes a rest. You should also make sure that your computer screen is at the correct height and distance from your eyes.

There is no chance of the other eye becoming affected by lazy eye. However, it is important to have regular eye exams to make sure that your vision is not deteriorating.

I hope this helps.

input: Hi doctor,I have had a terrible cough for weeks due to the flu. I decided to try Delsym 12 hour cough. It helped immensely, but the second day when I had it, I noticed a bit of restlessness and light sensitivity. I waited to take another dose and when I did take another dose, I took half of the recommended dose for adults. That was at 10 pm last night. Now, at almost 2 pm the next day and I am experiencing odd side effects. Sweaty palms, a bit of confusion, loss of attention, and light sensitivity. It feels like my eyes are dilated, but does not appear they are. Every day I take 20 mg of Vyvanse and 300 mg of Wellbutrin.
output: It is possible that the Delsym 12 hour cough is causing these side effects. Delsym contains dextromethorphan, which is a cough suppressant that can cause side effects such as restlessness, confusion, and light sensitivity. It is also possible that the combination of the Delsym and your other medications is causing these side effects. I would recommend that you stop taking the Delsym and speak to your doctor about other options for treating your cough. Your doctor may also want to adjust your other medications to reduce the risk of side effects.

input: Hi doctor,My son is 16 years old. He is suffering from constipation. What are the home remedies used to get rid of it?
output:
1. Increase fiber intake: Eating more fiber-rich foods, such as fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, can help to soften stools and make them easier to pass.

2. Stay hydrated: Drinking plenty of fluids, such as water, can help to keep stools soft and easy to pass.

3. Exercise regularly: Regular physical activity can help to stimulate the digestive system and reduce constipation.

4. Take probiotics: Probiotics are beneficial bacteria that can help to improve digestion and reduce constipation.

5. Try over-the-counter remedies: There are several over-the-counter laxatives and stool softeners that can help to relieve constipation.

6. Try herbal remedies: Herbal remedies, such as senna, psyllium husk, and aloe vera, can help to relieve constipation.

input: Hello doctor, For ten years, my husband has been successfully using an extended wear bandage contact lens (monthly wear) to control the pain of aphakic bullous keratopathy in one eye. About seven months ago, he had an episode of foreign body pain in the eye which the contact lens could not control. His optometrist changed the type of lens after remarking that the lens appeared tight. Although the painful sensations have decreased, they are still present with more of a sore feeling now. His ophthalmologist suggested that he discontinue the Azopt drops he had been using in case the preservative was causing some corneal toxicity. His eye pressure without the drops has read at 18 and 20 on separate occasions, but he does have corneal edema which may affect the measurement. He has had high pressure in that eye previously, but it was mostly lowered by Cyclodiode treatment some eight years ago. The consultant said he had left him on the Azopt drops just as a precaution. My query is that if the bandage lens has worked so well for pain management for 10 years is it possible that it can continue to work? And if the Azopt drops and their preservative had caused some toxic reaction seven months ago, could that still be causing him to feel the discomfort? His consultant suggested out that he could have the eye removed to control the pain, but as he has what he feels is some slight, useful vision in that eye, he does not want to take such a drastic and life-changing step. In fact, he wants to pursue the least invasive course of action to relieve the pain he is getting. I would appreciate any advice you could give as he is in quite a bit of pain.
output: It is possible that the bandage contact lens could continue to work for pain management, however it is difficult to say without further evaluation. It is also possible that the Azopt drops and their preservative could still be causing some discomfort, however it is difficult to say without further evaluation. I would recommend that your husband follow up with his ophthalmologist for further evaluation and to discuss the best course of action for pain management.

input: Hello doctor,I had a CBC (complete blood count) done yesterday and it came back with elevated WBC of 13500, with neutrophils 9000 (more or less), ESR 36, and close to normal lymphocytes. I am mentioning this because I read stress can be a factor.I am worried because my levels are elevated and I show no signs of infection apart from the eye (which still has a little pus). I do not go out due to COVID-19 at all. Food is delivered and handled in a very safe way, packages are disinfected and I have no contact with anyone. I am puzzled as to where an infection could come from. My doctor thinks it is a bacterial infection and has put me on antibiotics. I am very worried about cancer. Should I be?
output: It is possible that your elevated WBC count is due to stress, as stress can cause the body to produce more white blood cells. However, it is also possible that it is due to an underlying infection, which is why your doctor has prescribed antibiotics. It is unlikely that your elevated WBC count is due to cancer, as cancer typically causes a decrease in white blood cells. input: Hello doctor,My daughter who is 2.8 years old cried hard before two weeks and developed a hoarse voice the next day. It subsided in about three days. output: Hoarseness in a 2.8 year old is most likely due to a viral infection or irritation from crying. It is very unlikely that it is due to cancer. To help get rid of the hoarseness, you can try giving her warm liquids, such as tea or soup, and honey. You can also try using a humidifier in her room to help keep her throat moist. If the hoarseness persists, it is best to take her to the doctor for an evaluation.

Additionally, the pulmonologist may recommend additional medications or treatments, such as oxygen therapy, to help improve the patient's breathing.

input: Hi doctor,The imaging of the neck region was done and some lesions were detected. The operation of lower jaw and neck region was done followed by chemotherapy and radiotherapy and it was stated that things will settle to normal. During routine checkup, some swelling in neck region was detected and FNAC was done, which shows metastatic poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, and after that full-body scan was performed. The reports are attached. Kindly look into it as the second opinion is required.
output: I am sorry to hear about your diagnosis. It is important to get a second opinion from an oncologist or a specialist in head and neck cancer. The imaging and FNAC results suggest that the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. The full body scan will help to determine the extent of the spread and the best treatment options. It is important to discuss the results of the scan with your doctor and to consider all available treatment options.

input: Hello doctor,I had a tetanus shot last year around June. I had another minor mishap on the road with a small injury (cleaned with antiseptic). Do I need another tetanus shot now?
output: No, you do not need another tetanus shot. The tetanus shot you received last year should still be effective. However, if you have any concerns, it is best to speak with your doctor.

input: Hello doctor,Is hepatitis B transmitted by saliva? Hepatitis B virus is just detected in my body. My viral load is 1.5 * 10^5 count/mL. Is it possible for me to get totally cure for this disease? If it is possible how much time will it take to get totally cured?
output: Hepatitis B is transmitted through contact with infected blood, semen, and other body fluids. It is not transmitted through saliva. It is possible to get totally cured from hepatitis B, but it depends on the individual and the severity of the infection. Treatment usually takes several months, and in some cases, it can take up to a year or more. It is important to follow your doctor's instructions and take all medications as prescribed.

input: Hello doctor,I am 36 years old. I have depression, illness, and taking treatments for about 16 years. Now, taking Veniz XR 37.5, Thyronorm 50 mcg, both in the morning and Veniz XR 37.5, 75 both are evening. Feeling fatigue and anorexia. I do not like doing work, feel restlessness, and intensely angry. These symptoms are feeling compulsive looking in the smartphone, porn sites, and porn stars detail, and masturbate two to three times daily. Now, while looking on erotic porn stars videos, heartbeat and anxiety are high. Is it porn addiction? And what are the symptoms of porn addiction? Porn addiction and intense anxiety have any relation? Please answer me.
output: Porn addiction is a real issue and can be very damaging to one's mental health. The symptoms of porn addiction include compulsive viewing of porn, feeling an urge to view porn, feeling guilty or ashamed after viewing porn, and spending an excessive amount of time viewing porn. It is possible that your intense anxiety and porn addiction are related, as anxiety can be a symptom of addiction. It is important to speak to a mental health professional about your symptoms and to get help in managing your addiction.

input: Hi doctor,I have just received results back from a blood test that says my red blood cell count is quite high. I am a 35-year-old female and I am a smoker (between 4 to 7 a day). I began to get headaches, dizzy spells, nausea, fatigue, and itchiness all over the past five weeks. I do not know whether or not a miscarriage could count towards what is going on or not but I would like to know what it is I should do. My doctor just said to quit smoking and come back in 12 weeks for another test.
output: It is important to follow your doctor's advice and quit smoking. Smoking can have a negative effect on your health and can contribute to a variety of health issues. Additionally, it is important to follow up with your doctor in 12 weeks for another test. It is possible that your high red blood cell count could be related to a miscarriage, but it is also possible that it could be related to other health issues. It is important to discuss your symptoms with your doctor and to get a full physical exam to determine the cause of your symptoms. Your doctor may also order additional tests to help diagnose the cause of your symptoms.

input: Hello doctor,I want to know about piles. For the past two days, I am having little bit pain in the anus. I want to know if it is piles or not.
output: Piles, also known as hemorrhoids, are swollen veins in the lower rectum or anus. Symptoms of piles include pain, itching, and swelling around the anus. If you are experiencing pain in the anus, it is important to see a doctor to determine the cause. Your doctor can perform a physical exam and may order tests to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment for piles may include lifestyle changes, medications, or surgery.

input: Hello doctor,I am writing for my daughter, staying away from us, with her husband. She is 30 years, 5 feet 1 inch and 63 kg, working in the IT sector. She is married for the last three years and seriously trying for conception from a year. She missed her period once in the beginning of this year. During her obstetrics consultation, beta hCG was done. It was repeated after two days. A transvaginal ultrasound scan was done and repeated after 10 days. The end result was diagnosed as a blighted ovum. So, it was evacuated by D and C.Our daughter is of normal build and nutrition. Her menstrual history was normal since the beginning in terms of cycle, duration, and flow. But, one month after D and C, she did not have her period. On the doctor's advice, she took some medicines and bleeding occurred. She was known hypothyroid. So, she was taking Thyroxin 50 or 75 to keep the TSH near about 2.5 Uiu/ml. Her Hb % and sugar are within the normal range.Again, she tried to conceive since three months ago along with Aspirin and folic acid. She missed her period last month. Her beta hCG was 9.20 mIu/ mL. It was repeated after two days. It came down to 1 Miu/ml suggestive of \chemical pregnancy\. This time, after a few days, a spontaneous jelly-like bleeding occurred for two days. I would like to add that her husband requires to take Penegra 50 mg tab before a performance. Our daughter is immunized with triple antigen, polio, MMR, chickenpox and hepatitis B vaccine in childhood. The transvaginal scan (done at a later phase of the first conception) showed normal anatomical and physiological pattern of the ovary and uterus to me at least (report attached).Two consecutive miscarriages brought great disappointment to all. Presently, the doctor told her to take Aspirin 150 mg, folic acid, and Vitamin B12 combination tablet and to try for pregnancy again. I want your valuable opinion regarding subsequent management or the right line of treatment and suggestions or tests (if any) to get a successful pregnancy and healthy baby.
output: It is difficult to give a definitive answer without a more detailed medical history and physical examination. However, it is important to ensure that your daughter is in good health before attempting to conceive again. This includes making sure that her thyroid levels are well controlled, that she is taking a prenatal vitamin with folic acid, and that she is eating a healthy diet. Additionally, it may be beneficial for her to discuss her medical history with her doctor to determine if any additional tests or treatments may be necessary. Additionally, it is important to ensure that her husband is taking any necessary medications to ensure that he is in good health before attempting to conceive.

input: Hello doctor,I am 31 year old male. My eardrum burst after coming down with the flu. It has been leaking this watery bloody substance. This happened about four hours ago. I was in pain till it burst. Seems like all the pressure went away and was a huge relief. My question is do I let it heal on its own or should I go see a doctor?
output: It is important to see a doctor as soon as possible. A burst eardrum can lead to hearing loss, infection, and other complications. Your doctor can assess the extent of the damage and provide treatment to help prevent further damage.

input: Hi doctor,I have reduced smoking. From past 30 days, I have only smoked maybe 10 to 12 cigarettes and trying to quit smoking. I had a dry cough but it was gone but sometimes I do a cough maybe three to four times in whole 24 hours. But while brushing my teeth today I was cleaning my tongue, I coughed up blood in my spit and then I went to really polluted area dust and smoke of burning tier. I was not able to breathe. Literally not able to breathe. So, I came home on purpose I coughed blood again and that cough was really from inside. I am scared is this lung cancer? But no pain in chest not breathless while running or anything. I am totally fine. No weight loss, I feel hungry. I am totally fine. Please help.
output: It is unlikely that you have lung cancer, as this is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, and weight loss. However, it is important to see a doctor to rule out any other possible causes of your symptoms. The doctor may order tests such as a chest X-ray or CT scan to help diagnose the cause of your coughing up blood. In the meantime, it is important to avoid exposure to pollutants and to continue to reduce your smoking.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 26 year old male. When I am with my friends (male), an image of kissing that friend pops into my head sometimes. Though I am not attracted to boys, what could be the reason for this? Please help.
output: It is possible that this is a sign of repressed feelings or desires that you may have. It is important to explore these feelings and understand why they are coming up. It could be related to a need for intimacy or connection, or it could be related to unresolved issues from your past. It is important to talk to a mental health professional to help you explore these feelings and understand why they are coming up.

input: Hello doctor,I feel as if I may have a neurodegenerative disease. My symptoms are as follows:More forgetful than normal.Battle to find the right words.I get very bad pains and pressure in my brain.When driving, I battle with judging my following distance.Please, could you provide any tests that I could take? If it is a neurodegenerative disease, what is the progression rate, that is, the timeline between each stage?
output: It is difficult to diagnose a neurodegenerative disease without a physical examination and further testing. I recommend that you make an appointment with your primary care physician or a neurologist to discuss your symptoms and determine if further testing is necessary. Depending on the type of neurodegenerative disease, the progression rate can vary greatly. Some diseases progress slowly over many years, while others can progress rapidly over a few months or years. Your doctor can provide more information about the progression rate of any particular neurodegenerative disease.

input: Hello doctor,I have had a lower back pain for the last couple of years. It all started after I lifted a stone at a cricket ground. A little amount of physiotherapy helped after the doctor\s advice. I have consulted three doctors in two years and a doctor advised MRI this week. My doctor is out until next week and I am very anxious to understand the MRI report. Kindly help me understand the report.
output: MRI reports can be difficult to interpret without the help of a doctor. It is important to have a doctor review the report to ensure that the results are accurate and to provide a proper diagnosis. The report will likely include information about the size and shape of the spine, any abnormalities, and any areas of inflammation or injury. It may also include information about the discs between the vertebrae, the nerves, and any other structures in the spine. Your doctor will be able to explain the results of the MRI and provide a diagnosis and treatment plan.

input: Hello doctor,I am 23 years old and just learned about transillumination of the scrotum. I did the exam on myself and my right testicle does not glow when the light is shinned under. I cannot feel any lumps on palpation. Should I get additional examination?
output: Yes, it is recommended that you get additional examination. Transillumination of the scrotum is not a definitive test for any condition, and it is important to get a full physical examination from a doctor to rule out any potential issues. Your doctor may also order additional tests such as an ultrasound or blood tests to further evaluate your condition.

input: Hello doctor,I fell off the bike. I took X-rays and the doctor is telling me that both elbows are broken. As a non-professional, I cannot see if it is really broken. I do not have any pain if I am not stretching the elbow too much. Are both elbows really broken? And if yes, do I have to wear the cast for 2 to 3 weeks?
output: It is difficult to answer your question without seeing the X-rays. It is possible that both elbows are broken, but it is also possible that only one is broken. If the X-rays show that both elbows are broken, then you will likely need to wear a cast for 2 to 3 weeks. However, it is best to follow the advice of your doctor.

input: Hello doctor,I had a question about the ketone diet. I honestly do not understand the benefits of a ketone diet, what are they? Is a ketone diet good for those who are diabetic?
output:
The ketogenic diet is a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet that has been used for many years to treat certain medical conditions, such as epilepsy. The diet works by forcing the body to burn fat instead of carbohydrates for energy, which produces ketones in the body. The ketones can then be used as an alternative fuel source for the body.

The benefits of a ketogenic diet include weight loss, improved blood sugar control, and improved cholesterol levels. It may also help reduce inflammation and improve brain function.

For those with diabetes, a ketogenic diet may be beneficial in helping to control blood sugar levels. However, it is important to speak with your doctor before starting any new diet, especially if you have diabetes.

input: Hello doctor,I flossed by a tooth where a filling almost came out and my tooth and gum have been hurting all night. Also have a tooth that is by this molar that fell or chipped out. I do not know if it is an abscess or an exposed nerve in my molar that is right behind it. Took Tylenol 2 every 6 hours twice. It did not help. Used Benzocaine on the area. Helped 20 %. Do not feel comfortable using it at home.
output: It is difficult to diagnose your condition without an examination. I recommend that you see your dentist as soon as possible to determine the cause of your pain and to determine the best course of treatment. Your dentist may recommend a root canal, a filling, or other treatment to address the issue. In the meantime, you can take over-the-counter pain medications such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen to help manage the pain.

input: Hi doctor,I have polycystic ovary syndrome and my periods get delayed sometimes. From the past four days, I am having pain in my left pelvic area. I got an ultrasound done, and it shows 4.5 cm cyst in my right ovary. Why am I having pain on my left side when the cyst is on the right? Could this pain be due to the cyst?
output: It is possible that the pain you are experiencing is due to the cyst. Cysts can cause pain due to their size and location. It is also possible that the pain is due to something else, such as endometriosis or pelvic inflammatory disease. It is important to speak to your doctor about your symptoms and have any necessary tests done to determine the cause of your pain.

input: Hi doctor,My 4 years son had a cough for two days. Now his cough is fine but now he has a high fever on the head side but his hands are ice cold. He is telling pain sometimes in hands and some times in feet. What is the cause? Please explain.
output: It is difficult to diagnose the cause of your son's fever without a physical examination. It is possible that he has an infection such as a viral or bacterial infection, or he may have an allergic reaction. It is important to take your son to the doctor for a physical examination and to determine the cause of his fever. The doctor may order tests such as a blood test or a chest x-ray to help diagnose the cause of the fever. Treatment will depend on the cause of the fever.

input: Hi doctor,My wife is indifferent to child health issues. She controls the child with threatening words. The child cannot cry or weep even with an extreme reprimand by her. She makes the child sleep under extreme pressure. Sometimes, the child wets the bed. She then becomes furious with him. All this has led him to be a withdrawn child and always compromising. Please suggest me.
output: It sounds like your wife's parenting style is causing your child to feel anxious and insecure. It is important to talk to your wife about her parenting style and how it is affecting your child. You can also suggest that she take a parenting class or read books on positive parenting techniques. It is also important to make sure your child has a safe and supportive environment to express their feelings and emotions. Encourage your child to talk to you about their feelings and provide them with a safe space to do so. Finally, make sure your child is getting enough sleep and is engaging in activities that help them relax and feel secure.

input: Hi doctor, I have been taking Effexor XR 300 mg for depression. It has been working really well. My psychiatrist has now prescribed me Strattera for ADHD. I am about to start 25 mg and work my way upto 80 mg over a few weeks. Strattera and Effexor both seem to inhibit Norepinephrine reuptake. Is it safe to take this combination? I know my psychiatrist knows what he is doing, but I wanted to get a second opinion from others.
output: It is generally safe to take Strattera and Effexor together, as long as you are monitored closely by your psychiatrist. It is important to note that both medications can increase the risk of serotonin syndrome, so it is important to be aware of the signs and symptoms of this condition. It is also important to be aware of any potential drug interactions between the two medications. It is best to discuss any concerns with your psychiatrist before starting the combination.
